transcripts.text: I mean, there's two ways to interpret the Tea Party, right?  One is as a sort of feckless and nihilistic enterprise that has led to this bad situation.  The other is a very effective political movement.  For instance, if you are organizing a political movement because you don't want action on climate change, the Tea Party was an effective movement.  They literally primaried you and got you out, and they delayed action on climate change.  So at some level, it's like, I wonder this all the time with progressive activists.  When you think, Heather, of Tea Party the left, do you think about that as a good or bad thing?

I think about the country we want to see.  Just the Green New Deal, this idea, even when pressure tested and talking about higher taxes and saying, oh my gosh, Democrats are proposing it, it's more popular than the Republican tax cuts, the $1.5 trillion we just found to give away to corporations and the wealthy.  It's more popular than the wall.  So I think when... We have this idea that left ideas are moving and shaking inside the political atmosphere right now.  It's true, but they're left in terms of the inside of Washington.  In terms of the American people, they're the centrist ideas because they're about taking back our democracy and our economy.

But I worry that what we do is if we have basically the mirror image of a Trump rally on climate change... that we drive all the people away that could come our way and solve this thing now, and then could we come back to things like universal basic income?  Could we come back to healthcare?  Because, you know, I was in two Congresses that were totally consumed by healthcare.  You can't do it in a single Congress, the entire Green New Deal.  It is literally impossible.  with the number of committee references that you would have in the course of that.  So is it possible that we say, listen, climate change is the thing that we're seeing, the whites of its eyes, we've got to act now.  Can we come back maybe to universal basic income a little bit later?
Hey, hey, hey, hey, that's unacceptable.
And that's the difference between me and Trump.

Only AOC could manage to handle a heckler without missing a beat and make Trump look bad doing it.  She was speaking about the Green New Deal at a town hall hosted by MSNBC's Chris Hayes, along with former Republican Congressman Bob Inglis, whose support for climate action actually led to his own defeat in a primary challenge in 2010.  In stark contrast to AOC's calls for sweeping changes championed by this new Congress, Inglis suggested focusing on one thing, the Green New Deal, for example, and saving other agenda items for later.  to use what he claims might be limited political capital on climate change and put everything else on the back burner.  The remark drew boos from the crowd, with one heckler calling him a moron, at which point Ocasio-Cortez shut him down immediately and, without skipping a beat, called Trump out for being absolutely incapable of doing the same.  And she's spot on.  Not only would Trump never call out one of his rally attendees for being awful, he feeds off it.  Forget shutting it down, he's the one instigating it.

confiscate his coat.  You know, it's about 10 degrees below zero outside.  He's going home to his mom.  Say hello to mommy.  You know, it's amazing.  I mentioned food stamps, and that guy who's seriously overweight went crazy.  He went crazy.

There's a guy, totally disruptive, throwing punches.  We're not allowed to punch back anymore.  I love the old days.  You know what they used to do to guys like that when they were in a place like this?  They'd be carried out on a stretcher, folks.
And that comes in stark contrast to the guy who Trump's predicated his entire presidency on comparing himself to.

Hold up.  Everybody sit down and be quiet for a second.  Everybody sit down and be quiet for a second.  Now listen up.  I'm serious.  Listen up.  You've got an older gentleman who is supporting his candidate.  He's not doing nothing.  You don't have to worry about him.  This is what I mean about folks not being focused.  First of all, first of all, hold up.  Hold up.  First of all, We live in a country that respects free speech.  So, second of all, it looks like maybe he might have served in our military, and we got to respect that.  Third of all, he was elderly, and we got to respect our elders.

And fourth of all, don't boo.  Don't boo.  Come on.  And we get it.  That's his brand.  He's a tough guy.  He can fire people.  And that's the persona he puts on and keeps up so that his base can say things like, he's not a regular politician.  But as much as he likes to hold rallies in red states to soak in the adulation, he's supposed to represent everyone in the country, supposed to work for those people, something he's never understood as his popularity sinks and something AOC understands as her popularity soars.
